general.headline: Chief Executive, Consumer Bank at Westpac Group
general.description:
George was appointed Chief Executive of Westpac Group’s Consumer Bank in June 2015 and is responsible for managing the end to end relationship with consumer customers. This includes all consumer banking products and services under the Westpac, St.George, BankSA, Bank of Melbourne and RAMS brands.  

Prior to this appointment, George was CEO, St.George Banking Group. He joined the Westpac Group in March 2009 as Chief Executive, Westpac New Zealand Limited. Formerly George was Group Executive General Manager at National Australia Bank and prior to that, a senior executive in Commonwealth Bank of Australia's Institutional Banking Division.  He has also been a partner with the Boston Consulting Group and an officer in the Royal Australian Air Force.

In addition to being one of Australia’s most experienced financial services executives, George is a highly sought after board and advisory committee executive.  His current positions include;
•  Chair, Prime Minister’s Industry Advisory Committee on Veterans’ Employment
•  Chair, St George Bank
•  Board member, Bank of Melbourne
•  Governor, St George Foundation
•  Co-founder, Head Start Homes
•  Advisory Committee, UNSW Business School 

George is a passionate supporter and actively involved with numerous charities, including;
•  Amnesty 2020, Council member 
•  St Vincent’s Curran Foundation 
•  The Hellenic Initiative, board member

jobs.description:
George is responsible for managing the end to end relationship with consumer
      customers across all consumer banking products and services under the Westpac,
      St.George, BankSA, Bank of Melbourne and RAMS brands.
      

    
      

    Westpac’s Consumer Bank is comprised of approximately 11,000 employees, and has a
      strong distribution network with more than 1,100 branches across Australia.

A division of Westpac Banking Corporation, St.George Banking Group is comprised of 4,600 people working across the St.George Bank, Bank of Melbourne, BankSA and RAMS brands. St.George Banking Group experienced tremendous momentum under George’s leadership with six positives halves of growth; cash earnings (profit after tax) increased by 14% in the 2014 financial year and 17% in the 2013 financial year. In the first half of the 2015 financial year, St.George Banking Group was the largest contributor to Westpac Group's cash earnings growth

George had full end-to-end responsibility for Westpac New Zealand’s retail, business,
      wealth and institutional businesses. He was instrumental in improving the performance
      of the Westpac New Zealand business, with cash earnings tripling over the three years
      
      and home loans growing at twice the banking system average.

general.headline: Group Head of Financial Crime & Fraud, Westpac Banking Corporation
general.description:
Susie is a respected leader in the Australian financial services risk management industry, with a deep wealth of experience spanning over 25 years across financial crime, fraud, retail credit risk, and operational risk. Susie holds both a Bachelor of Commerce (Sydney University) and Executive Masters of Business Administration (MBA AGSM). 

As the Group Head of Financial Crime and Fraud for the Westpac Group, Susie is accountable for ensuring effective global financial crime risk management and compliance, encompassing fraud, money laundering, terrorism financing, anti-bribery and corruption, economic and trade sanctions, and tax evasion. This international role covers all retail and institutional banking divisions globally, including the Americas, Asia and Australasia. The scope of the role includes extensive transformation of financial crime global systems and process, strategic vendor management, and engagement with global regulators. In 2016 Susie’s contribution was recognized by being awarded the Westpac Risk Leader of the Year 2016, in addition to the CEO Service Revolution Award 2016. 

Susie’s prior roles within the Westpac Group include Head of Secured Risk, Head of Unsecured Risk and Fraud, all of which held accountability for credit policy and portfolio management, credit operations management, credit process re-engineering, as well as credit risk systems, tools and data development and management.   

Susie is a current board director of the Financial Crimes Exchange (FCE), and a former board director of the Australian Retail Credit Association (ARCA), the Banking Financial Services Ombudsman (BFSO), and a former advisor of the Banking Advisory Board for the Financial Ombudsman Service (FOS).

In my role leading Rabobank’s Wholesale Bank in Australia and New Zealand, I am dedicated to helping our customers realise their business goals and helping them solve the problems they face.

With 18 years’ experience in the financial services industry across a variety of customer facing roles, I believe firmly in the importance of strong customer relationships built on trust, respect and advocating for their success. Engaging with the customer, creating value for both the customer and the bank, leading relationship teams and bringing an exceptional depth of knowledge of banking solutions and tailored products is what I most enjoy about working in Wholesale Banking.  

I am also passionate about feeding the world sustainably, and how the food and agri value chain can adapt to produce more with less.  At Rabobank, together with our clients, partners and colleagues, we want to contribute to the four dimensions of food security: increasing the availability of food, improving access to food, promoting balanced nutrition and increasing stability.

general.headline: General Manager Retail Broker  ANZ
general.school: Massachusetts Institute of Technology - Sloan School of Management
general.description:
Simone Tilley has a strong breadth across the business landscape working in Commercial, Corporate and Institutional Banks.  She has  ~20 years frontline experience in addition to leading her own family's manufacturing business (40 FTE), whilst also starting up a packaging business from scratch, later selling to a multi-national.  

Simone currently is the GM for ANZ's Retail Broker Division, responsible for ~56% of ANZ's Australian Retail Divisions lending flows, Third Party Deposits business ~8% deposit FUM for Australia Division.  

As a result of her transformative work uptiering governance, monitoring and oversight frameworks for the Retail Broker business, it has enabled the ANZ Retail Broker division to lead  many initiatives first to market.  

As a result of intense regulatory scrutiny by ASIC and Sedgwick, the industry recognised the urgent need for self regulation. Simone was appointed co-lead for the Governance, Data and Reporting stream in the Combined Industry Forum (CIF) where selected lenders, aggregators, industry bodies, ABA, Choice Consumer group and broker businesses, corralled to solve for regulatory issues to enable the third party industry to self regulate.   

Prior to this role,  she led Regional Business Banking Victoria and Tasmania, covering both Agribusiness and Commercial customers.  She also double hatted as National Head of Commercial Regional Bank, setting and executing strategy on a national scale.  

Previously, she was Director, Institutional Bank, setting and executing strategy for Global Agribusiness across ANZ's Global footprint.  

Simone has a broad perspective and varied experience spanning small business to institutional bank together with her own experience running a business in her own right.  She is renown for delivering performance excellence, leading transformational change whilst delivering financial outperformance through a highly engaged team.

general.description:
Milan is an entrepreneur who has led IT solution business, Gratex International Australia, for more than 13 years, balancing a strong vision for the business value of technology with conservative business acumen.

In his business, he has the ability to bring together the best of both worlds; the leading edge of Information Technology combined with traditional values of 100% quality in service delivery and uncompromising commitment to customer outcomes.

For Milan, business is personal, he assures through dedicated expert staff and focus on quality that customers can always rely on Gratex’ commitment to deliver, “no matter what”. His local organisation is closely aligned and supported by Gratex International headquartered in Europe.

He proactively fosters his company’s values of “genuine customer care”, “quality” and “local service excellence”. Committed to create local workplace, the entire delivery team as well as the data centre is located in Australia.

Milan is a member of Australian Institute of Company directors.

Milan accepted in 2012 the appointment as Honorary Consul for the Slovak Republic and fosters the mutual value of economic relationships with Australia.

Gratex International Australia helps organisations to transition their IT systems from traditional models to hybrid and/or cloud based system solutions that are fully aligned with business objectives and deliver measurable productivity improvements or cost reductions.

www.gratex.com.au

Gratex Insurance Solutions helps insurance agencies and insurers to increase the value of their business through process automation that results in increased staff productivity while lowering cost. Innovative, industry specific business systems and software development solutions based on best-practice are tailored to specific business needs in order to maximise the return on investment.

general.headline: Director - Private Debt at FIIG Securities
general.description:
FIIG Securities Limited is Australia’s leading fixed income specialist, with over A$11 billion currently under investment. For over 19 years FIIG has been providing investors with direct access to bond markets and a range of term deposits and other cash solutions. 

Direct: +612 9697 8778    
Email: Erryn.Lloyd-Jones@fiig.com.au
Website: https://www.fiig.com.au/services/debt-capital-markets 

Erryn is a senior Institutional Banker with extensive client coverage background in Global Corporates, Financial Institutions & Corporate Real Estate sectors.

jobs.description:
FIIG Private Debt is responsible for originating, executing, managing and syndicating
      private financing opportunities for mid-market and property companies utilising debt
      sourced from FIIG’s existing institutional and professional investors. Private Debt will
      typically distribute debt investments from $10m - $100m using financial instruments
      across the capital structure including; senior, junior and mezzanine debt and
      
      convertible notes incorporating, where necessary, PIK and warrant structures.

Arranging rated and unrated, long tenor bond funding for Australian businesses in the sectors of Property, Infrastructure, Mid-Market Corporate and NBFI. FIIG Debt Capital Markets has arranged 45 bond issues raising over A$1.9 billion. These issues have been for a term of 4yrs+, fixed and floating rate, secured and unsecured for a diverse range of private and public companies including: Zip Money, Elanor Investors Group, Merredin Energy, Lucas Total Contract Solutions, Liberty Financial, Axsesstoday, NRW Holdings, StockCo AgriFinance, Capitol Health, IMF Bentham, Sunland Group, CML Group, IPG Logistics, G8 Education, SCT Logistics, Dicker Data and Plenary Group. 

FIIG is a leading arranger of unrated, long tenor bond funding for Australian corporates. Australian corporates have historically been reliant on sourcing debt capital from the bank market. To help unrated Australian companies diversify their borrowings, FIIG Debt Capital Markets has tailored a bond offering similar in structure to those issued by larger rated corporates in offshore markets but in $A.

Corporate Banking Originations VIC and TAS

Origination, structuring and execution of exclusively new-to-bank client relationships including large private companies and mid-cap listed organisations. 

Focus on cash flow funding for working capital, capital expenditure programs and acquisition finance requirements.

Cross sales of financial markets risk management for interest rates, foreign exchange and commodity hedging.

Cross sales of transactional banking and data and insights.

Managing Bank relationships across Oil & Gas, Mining & Property by co-ordinating ‘whole of bank solutions’ with assistance from product partners to generate cross sell income to support use of balance sheet. 

Tier 1 client portfolio includes multinational companies; Exxon, Puma Energy, Newcrest Mining, Barrick, Oil Search and other large companies based in PNG. 

Key focus on foreign exchange sales and hedging, transactional banking, trade finance as well as deposit taking and lending in USD & Kina to a range of bilateral and syndicated facilities.

general.headline: Town Planner at City of Canada Bay Council
general.description: 5 years professional experience in Statutory Planning (Development Assessment) in the context of Local Government - having roles in several Councils & a leading Planning consultancy - within Sydney. I am currently studying the Master of Heritage Conservation at the University of Sydney, having completed two-thirds of this post graduate program.

jobs.description:
Working as a Town Planner in the Statutory Planning Services team at the City of
      Canada Bay Council. The City of Canada Bay is located upon the Parramatta River with
      generous frontage to Syndey Harbour and contains rich cultural and architectural
      
      heritage.

I worked as a Planner in the Assessment Teams and was responsible for the assessment of Development Applications and other related applications (for e.g. section 96 Modification of Development Consent) assessed under Section 79(C)(1) of the EP & A Act 1979 (NSW). 

The DAs and s.96 Applications I assessed and determined involved, or related to the following:
- alterations & additions to existing residential dwellings (i.e. detached or semi-detached dwelling).
- vast majority of applications in respect to properties containing a local heritage item or located within a Heritage Conservation Area (HCA).
- modifications to development consents for residential dwellings and commercial properties/tenancies.

I worked within the Planning Assessment Teams branch within Sutherland Shire Council (SSC). The chief duties of this challenging DA Planning role included:
a) Assessing proposed development (low to medium density residential and retail premises) and making recommendations on the determinations of Development Applications (DAs) and Section 96 (Modification of Consent) Applications having regard to the Heads of Considerations outlined in Section 79(C) of the NSW Environmental Planning & Assessment Act 1979, and relevant building regulations required by the National Construction Code (formerly Building Code of Australia) and the Australian Standards.
b) Providing 'duty planning' advice to professionals (for e.g. architects, consultant town planners, engineers, etc.) and the general public by explaining State Government policies and Council's planning controls, and clarifying requirements for the submissions of DAs.
c) I worked in Council's specialist Dual Occupancy team for 6 months (July 2015 - January 2016), where I was responsible for the management and assessment of DAs for Dual Occupancies which were lodged under the new Sutherland Shire Local Environmental Plan 2015 (SSLEP 2015). Effective co-ordination of technical advice from Council's traffic planning, engineering & environmental branches was critical in the quality assessment of such infill development. 
d) Key planning issues encompassed view sharing, bushfire prone land, management of the Shire's established tree canopy and infill development in residential zoned areas designated for higher densities.

In this Council position I was responsible for the assessment of Development Applications (including s96 modification and s82A review applications), enforcement action in respect to breaches of development consent, and providing general Planning advice to the public and professionals consultants (planners, architects & engineers, etc.). This Town Planner position was within the Development Services branch of Mosman Council. 

Chief highlights of this role included:
- 'View sharing'​ assessment of iconic views of Sydney Harbour and the Heads.
- Significant experience in assessing proposals, both residential & commercial properties, within heritage conservation areas (HCAs) and in relation to local heritage items.
- Assessed and project managed the progress of contentious proposals for mixed use developments within HCAs which re-activated the subject sites, and also enhanced the streetscapes of the Military Road HCA & Middle Head Road. These DAs were reported to & determined by Council's MDAP (i.e. IHAP). 
- Experience as Council's appointed  Planning expert witness in Class 1 appeals to the NSW Land & Environment Court, including both s.34 conciliation (negotiation with the applicant) and judgment proceedings.
- Assessed many developments of high architectural design merit and occupant amenity within an urban, harbourside environment with demanding expectations from the local community for high quality planning outcomes.
- I learnt and implemented highly quality governance & customer service in the Local Government context, and contributed to the work of an innovative and capable Planning Assessment team.

I completed 12 months full-time professional experience as a Student Planner at the consultancy GSA Planning in Sydney. In this role I worked on a variety of projects and assisted the GSA Planning team in the following:
•	Prepared planning reports on residential development for Development Applications 
•	Prepared advice for Partners through investigating Council’s planning controls
•	Assisted partners in meetings with clients and helped to co-ordinate projects by liaising with Council officers, architects and sub-consultants, such as civil engineers.
•	Undertook site inspections for due diligence purposes and lodged Development Applications (DAs) at Councils

The chief achievements as a Student Planner are that I have gained a strong understanding of the operations of a planning consultancy and familiarity with lodging development applications at Councils. Additionally, I have gained the ability to interpret and advise GSA's partners on Local Government (Council) statutory and non-statutory planning policies, such as Local Environmental Plans and Development Control Plans. schools.description: I am currently studying full-time the Masters of Heritage Conservation at the University of Sydney. I have a genuine interest in historic buildings, heritage conservation areas, and places of cultural significance, and I am becoming further qualified to work in the heritage conservation profession. With the NSW Government's clear policy desire to further increase housing supply in Sydney and to provide the associated critical infrastructure to accommodate future population growth, there is a pressing need to ensure new development does not result in the loss of, or damage to, culturally and historically significant places. I am passionate to use my Local Council DA planning experience & knowledge in the effort to protect and manage culturally significant places for the sake of future generations. I also believe the amenity of our local communities, and the sense of belonging to them, can be improved and enhanced through high quality heritage conservation practice.

general.headline: Legal Intern at Australian Human Rights Commission
general.description:
I am currently undertaking a five year Bachelor of Laws/Communications Degree at the University of Technology Sydney and am currently in the penultimate year of my studies.

I am highly motivated by issues of social justice and have been involved in several opportunities for leadership throughout my Primary School, High School and University education including the St Aloysius' College Bellarmine Academy and the UTS Brennan Justice Program.

I am also proficient in writing and researching academic materials and frequently contribute to publications such as 'The Full Bench' of the UTS Law Students' Society.

jobs.description:
After having run a campaign for this position throughout October 2017, I was enormously grateful and humbled to accept the responsibilities of being the UTS Law Student's Society's incumbent Publications Director for 2018.

In this role, I will be responsible for creating multiple written submissions to, as well as co-ordinating student contributors and fellow members of the Educations Portfolio around, the written publications of the Law Student's Society such as their triannual journal 'The Full Bench' and weekly electronic newsletter 'The Buzz'. Such responsibilities ultimately go in service towards maintaining the high standard of LSS publications and honoring the amazing work done by past Publications Directors in pursuing this mission.

During my studies at UTS, I have heavily involved myself with opportunities to submit to student and private publications such as the UTS magazine 'Vertigo' and the Australian blog of the Brussels-based 'ILA Reporter'.

The main passion that informs my writing is my interest in politics and law, especially Australian constitutional law and the rights that have been applied from it thanks to the creative minds of High Court judges and policy makers. However, I also occasionally like to write pieces on popular culture and film.

The Two Wolves Cantina has provided me with an amazing opportunity to mesh practical hospitality and bar skills with a friendly, passionate work team who are fully committed to the social justice ideals of the Cardoner Project.

In my time at the Two Wolves, I have learnt several skills integral to a bar 'all rounder' such as waiting, till working, cocktail making, beer pouring and dish washing. I owe my learning of these skills to the kind and patient fellow volunteers and management of the Two Wolves, who are always ready to help even on the busiest of nights.

In addition, the Two Wolves allows me to mesh these skills with a volunteer ethos that distributes funds from the services we provide towards the social justice and volunteering opportunities provided by the Cardoner project abroad such as immersions in the Philippines and Cambodia.

The Refugee Advice and Casework Service has provided me with some of the most amazing practical experience in my legal studies as well as several invaluable opportunities to connect with professionals and fellow law students who are passionate about refugee rights and refugee law.

My experience at RACS has ranged from receiving clients, lawyers and interpreters on Monday and Wednesday clinics at UTS before escorting them to their appointment room to helping fill in client statement forms based on their immigration papers in the initial stages of their application for asylum.

Most recently, I helped in updating the central spreadsheet for each client's progress at the RACS main office as well as sending calls to clients (along with an interpreter on skype) who needed to apply before the deadline on October 01st. These were both intimidating, yet necessary tasks needing to be done. Thanks to the help of RACS senior staff and the strong teamwork I experienced with other UTS volunteers on those days, we managed to get both of them done.

For various clients, I would take care of their pet dogs while they were away on holidays. Although this is casual work, it nonetheless demands commitment and dedication in seeing through activities that keep the dogs in good health (such as walking them early in the morning) as well as, in some cases, an alertness to their medical conditions and the medication needed to be given to them.

This role involved the scanning of each individual book in the 'travel' section shelf-by-shelfy, followed by a physical re-count of those books before I proceeded to the next shelf.  After having counted each book on every shelf in a cabinet, I would submit the form of my physical count and upload the data from my scanner to the central database before proceeding onto the next cabinet.

This role demanded intense concentration, patience and physical endurance. To correctly register the books in each cabinet, I always sought to be as accurate as possible by re-scanning as many times as necessary to align my data with my physical count. Sometimes this would involve scanning individual books which were heavy and cumbersome to hold.

I chose to study law and communications because I have a particular fondness for well-reasoned arguing and an acute sense of justice. I like the stimulation offered by high pressure environments and am currently building my legal skillset working as a paralegal in insurance and corporate law.

In my pursuit of self-improvement, I have come to know myself more intently. I strive to continuously harness this awareness, which encompasses my weaknesses, gifts, distractions and motivations, to more astutely pursue and accomplish all that I feel called to. 

I care about people and I am deeply relational. I want to leave the world having made a meaningful contribution to the lives of others and so I seek to create a life of purpose in all I do. 

My passions include writing music and mental health advocacy. I consider myself to be highly articulate, fiercely determined and profoundly analytical. I pride myself on my ability to connect to other people through empathy and vulnerability. My affinity with language is evident in my tendency to express myself through words. While I can be outspoken, my instinct to speak my mind is a trait of mine that I hope will always prevail when given a choice between honesty and silence.

general.headline: Solicitor | Chief Executive Officer | Public & Policy Adviser | Social Entrepreneur | Journalist
general.description:
Sayed Rahmatullah Hussainizada has a strong passion for human rights, social justice and diplomatic solution to pressing issues within our society. He is an MC and a public speaker on social issues, refugee rights and cultural intelligence. 

Fluent in Dari, Farsi and moderate understanding of Urdu, Hindi and with basic knowledge of Indonesian, Sayed plans to build his career as an international lawyer and freelance journalist. He has a pronounced interest in the importance of diplomacy to address national and international issues to expand Australia's global role. Such issues include the need for cultural intelligence (CQ) and appreciation of diversity in the corporate and political sectors, raising the voices of unrepresented and disadvantaged people, particularly youth and raising awareness and acknowledgment of refugee entrepreneurism.  

Sayed runs Afghan Fajar Association Incorporated (AFAIC) -  a not-for-profit organisation that aims to establish a vibrant and connected Australia by providing education, assistance, social and cultural services to people of multicultural and disadvantaged backgrounds to grow an inclusive and harmonious nation. He sits on the advisory and board of directors of several not-for-profit organisations. Sayed is starting his own social enterprise focusing on culture and employment of migrants/refugees and people from disaster affected areas. 

Sayed has a Double Degree in Law and Journalism from the University of Technology Sydney. Sayed's goal is to combine his professional experience in the not-for-profit sector and strategic development with his interest in the law and the media. 

Sayed is the Winner of the Elizabeth Hastings Memorial Award for Student Community Contribution at he 2016 UTS Human Rights Awards. 

Specialities/Interests: 
- Anything Law
- Refugee Rights
- Project Management
- Event Planning
- Public Speaker
- Social Entrepreneur
- Human Rights 
- Social enterprise
- International volunteerism

general.headline: Policy Analyst at Universities Australia
general.description:
I have experience as a journalist, sociologist and consultant on three continents. I gained my PhD in sociology from the Australian National University in 2010 and have a specialised interest in skilled migration and identity. I have a wide range of academic interests including qualitative research methodology and the relationship between individual lives and the processes of globalisation. I am currently based in Xiamen, China. 

My first book "Transnational Lives in China: Expatriates in a Globalizing City" was published by Palgrave MacMillan in January 2014.

Specialties: Migration; the sociology of globalisation; transnationalism; identities; ethnicity and 'race'; gender; inequalities; writing for various audiences; communication of social research findings; China.

jobs.description:
UTS Nepalese society is a distinctive student-run non-profit organization, which was founded to preliminarily act as a networking society for Nepalese at UTS, and promote the diverse culture of Nepal. However, with the years of its execution, UTS Nepalese society has amplified its vision and workings. Today, UTS Nepalese society aims to uplift multiculturalism at UTS and help create lifelong relationships between the members from different backgrounds. 

UTS Nepalese Society (UNS) runs under the support of Activate UTS with a target to hold several multi- cultural programs, social events, and sporting events for its members, as well as other students at UTS. Additionally, the other interest of the society is to create a platform for development of interpersonal and critical life skills to all its members and volunteers. As a developing society at UTS, UNS plans to grow its networks and members around the corners of UTS. 

Over the years, UNS has successfully organized several immense as well as minor successful events at UTS, and thus, is recognized as one of the fastest growing societies within UTS community and outside.
